Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) will snap up Wilson Therapeutics for $855 million in a move that helps it diversify from its blockbuster franchise and compete with Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) and Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA).The acquisition of Wilson adds a "much-needed" late-stage asset, RBC analyst Kennen MacKay said. Alexion's biggest product, Soliris, brought in 88% of sales in 2017. Soliris treats two blood diseases and a neuromuscular condition. It's also making a follow-up drug called ALXN1210."Investors have increasingly focused on Alexion's business development efforts to diversify revenue/value away from Soliris/ALXN1210," he said in a note to clients. "As such, we anticipate this transaction could help add positive sentiment to the stock.But investors weren't as keen on the buy as MacKay had expected. On the stock market today, Alexion fell 2.4% to close at 110.79. At the same time, the broader biotech group advanced 0.2%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UsePiper Jaffray analyst Christopher Raymond noted that Alexion shareholders are still waiting for more data on ALXN1210 before giving the stock some love. He sees ALXN1210 as a potential $500 million peak product, which would be meaningful to the biotech with $4 billion revenue."This remains a show-me stock for now," he said in a report to clients. "With most investors waiting for ALXN1210's (switch-over from Soliris) study results, we understand this name is likely to remain in a trading range until then."The acquisition also could help Alexion compete with Valeant, which offers two highly priced treatments called Cuprimine and Syprine to treat Wilson disease. Wilson Therapeutics is targeting Wilson disease with a late-stage drug called WTX101.WTX101 answers two significant unmet needs, Piper Jaffray's Raymond said. Wilson disease occurs when excess copper builds up in tissues including the liver and brain, leading to organ damage. The condition isn't adequately treated by the current standard of care."This would also compete with some of Valeant's more controversially priced drugs," he said.Price increases for Cuprimine and Syprine were "front and center" during the public outcry over spiking drug prices, Raymond said. He added the two drugs can cost anywhere from $8,000 to $300,000 annually.Syprine was invented decades ago. Valeant acquired it and Cuprimine in 2010. The firm gained notoriety in 2015 when it raised the price to $21,267 from $652 just five years earlier. Teva just announced it will begin offering a costly generic of Syprine."We think this history perhaps gives Alexion some options on pricing for WTX101, as it could offer a heavy discount and still have a nicely priced product," he said.RBC's MacKay sees about 28,000 Wilson disease patients in the U.S. and Europe. Leerink analyst Geoffrey Porges estimates 10,000 patients in the U.S. and Europe each.The current standard of care includes avoiding copper-containing foods and a therapy called copper chelation, which detoxifies a patient's blood. But there's still an unmet need in those who have advanced forms of the disease, RBC's MacKay said."While these therapies are seen as effective, patient compliance/adherence is seen as an unmet need, which is critical toward maintaining a good long-term prognosis," he said.Alexion will pay the $855 million through cash on hand. The bid mostly empties the biotech's coffers, MacKay said. However, he does see the potential for the firm to make smaller deals going forward.Alexion's board unanimously approved the offer, and Wilson recommended shareholders accept it. Close to three-quarters of Wilson's shareholders have either agreed to or expressed support for the offer. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter."The Wilson acquisition also continues to broaden Alexion's rare disease therapeutic footprint beyond its core strength in complement/hematology," MacKay said.Leerink's Porges sees WTX101 as a solid strategic fit for Alexion. Alexion has expertise in liver diseases. It could also parlay its commercial footprint for three approved therapies into selling WTX101, he said in a note.WTX101 is also in a stronger position than the drug Kanuma, which Alexion acquired along with Synageva BioPharma in 2015. Kanuma treats a condition known as Wolman disease, which happens when the body doesn't produce enough of a specific enzyme.Alexion struggled following its launch of Kanuma. The drug brought in $65.6 million in sales in 2017. Porges blamed Kanuma's lackluster sales for souring "investors on Alexion's business development acumen."He's hoping the acquisition of Wilson Therapeutics could show management's willingness to assume clinical risk for more moderate cash outlays."Unlike the requirement with Kanuma to find and diagnose patients to drive revenue growth, Wilson disease patients are generally diagnosed and actively managed by hepatologists or neurologists, which would make initiating patients on WTX101 relatively easier," he said.RELATED:How To Tame A Volatile Swing Trade With A Half PositionLong-Term Retirement Investing Strategies With ETFsNew Option Strategy Limits Risk Around Earnings

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) stock broke out Wednesday, while Las Vegas Sands (LVS) rallied. But mutual funds and other institutional buyers weren't making big bets on the casino giants.They are two of the big players in the booming Macau market, along with MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Melco Resorts & Entertainment (MLCO). Privacy Policy & Terms of UseLate Wednesday, Wynn Resorts named three women to an expanded board, Betsy Atkins, Dee Dee Myers and Wendy Webb. The casino giant's top shareholder, Elaine Wynn, had demanded a board overhaul and corporate governance improvements in the wake of the abrupt February resignation of her ex-husband Steve Wynn as CEO.Wynn stock rose a fraction in after-hours action.Shares of Wynn tumbled in late January on reports of widespread, serious sexual misconduct charges vs. then-CEO Steve Wynn. Steve Wynn soon resigned and has since  sold all his shares in the casino giant, ending boardroom turmoil and easing regulatory concerns.Las Vegas Sands stock climbed 1.25% to 74.42. After retaking its 50-day line this week, Sands is moving toward a 79.94 buy point.MGM Resorts International advanced 0.8% to 36.41, working on a consolidation with a 38.51 entry. Morgan Stanley's Allen raised his price target on MGM earlier in the week.Melco Resorts & Entertainment rose 1% to 31.71, still in buy range. The Hong Kong-domiciled company cleared a 30.59 entry on April 12 in heavy volume.Wynn leads the Leisure-Gaming/Equipment Group, and has an excellent IBD Composite Rating of 95. Morgan Stanley's Allen said Wynn is in a good position to benefit from China's gaming boom due to its Macau casinos.He said this is important given uncertainties regarding its new property in Massachusetts and the ongoing managerial issues following Steve Wynn's February resignation."We are warming up to WYNN again given it has the most exposure in our coverage to the attractive Macau market and likely continues to have the opportunity to outperform through its ramping Cotai property," he said in a research note.He also said the company has done a very good job diminishing legal and regulatory overhangs. However he believes regulatory risk remains, particularly in Massachusetts, where construction of a $2.5 billion casino is ongoing.Meanwhile, Las Vegas Sands was given a one dollar target price increase by Morgan Stanley's Allen, to 83. He said it looks like the best bet when it comes to penetrating the Chinese market."We see LVS as best positioned for the longer term Macau " 'China penetration'/mass market story,"Allen said in a research note. "(We) believe the company should be an outsized beneficiary of increasing infrastructure tailwinds."Allen also said it is well positioned to operate in new gaming locations such as Japan and Korea.Sands has a Composite Rating of 89 and ranks third in the group.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:MGM Resorts International May Bet Big On Bid For Wynn Resorts Top Casino Stock Nears Buy Point Amid Strong Macau Growth Bullish Chart Patterns: Do You Know The Basics Of A Cup With Handle?Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

Crude oil prices rallied to their highest levels since 2014 Wednesday after U.S. inventories dropped, following fresh signs that OPEC and Russia will stay the course with their output cuts.XOPEC and Russian officials will meet in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, later this week to discuss extending cuts beyond the planned expiration at year's end, even as the global supply glut is nearly vanished and geopolitical tensions have sparked worries of a supply squeeze."Would they declare victory now and stop? No way," said Mike Wittner, head of oil market research at Societe Generale SA told Bloomberg. "They're happy to see inventories continue to go down, to see prices of $70 or $80. In the end, it's about revenue. The question is at what point do they become uncomfortable with higher prices?"Last month, Saudi Arabia, the de facto leader of OPEC, reportedly hinted that the cartel would continue coordinating production cuts with non-OPEC members into 2019.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseOil prices also got a boost after President Trump fired missiles at Syria last week in response to a suspected chemical weapons attack by the Syrian regime, while the continuing economic crisis in Venezuela also added to supply concerns.U.S. crude rose 2.9% to $68.47 a barrel, topping $68 for the first time in more than three years. Brent rose to about $73 a barrel.Exxon Mobil (XOM) shares closed up 1.1% on the stock market today. Chevron (CVX) added 1.9%. BP (BP) jumped 2.1%, and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) surged 2.3%, with both nearing buy points.Meanwhile, the Energy Information Administration said midday Wednesday that domestic stockpiles fell by 1.1 million barrels last week, and gasoline supplies dropped by 2.97 million barrels.Analysts polled by S&P Global Platts expect a 625,000-barrel increase in crude stockpiles and a 1.9 million-barrel drop in gasoline stockpiles.Late Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute, an industry group, reported a 1 million-barrel drop in crude stockpiles and a 2.5 million-barrel drop in gasoline stockpiles.U.S. oil production climbed to a fresh high of 10.54 million barrels a day last week from 10.53 million a week earlier, according to EIA data.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Energy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalThe 5 Oil Stocks Are Still On Fire Even As Crude CoolsNational Oilwell Varco Warns On Delayed Offshore Rig Construction

The first-quarter earnings season has been a good one for leading tech stocks involved in hot online businesses such as cloud computing services, internet advertising and subscription video on demand. The FANG stocks have shown particular strength, though, thanks to those businesses.Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) all cheered the market with their March-quarter reports.They stand in contrast to other facets of tech, such as the chip sector. That group has been struggling this earning season, especially those companies exposed to the maturing smartphone market.Suppliers to Apple's (AAPL) iPhone have been hard hit as news reports point to cuts in production orders. Investors also are worried that the semiconductor sector could be entering a down cycle. Pockets of strength include memory chips and graphics processors. Get Free Access To IBD Digital Through April 29

Get premium stock lists, pass or fail stock ratings and more. Start HereFacebook shook off recent data privacy concerns with its first-quarter results late Wednesday, which blew past expectations. Facebook's revenue rose 49% year over year to $11.97 billion, topping the 47% growth seen in the previous two quarters and showing the strength of its advertising-based social networking service. Earnings per share rose 63% to $1.69."We think that ads is a great business model that is aligned with our mission," Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg said on a conference call with analysts. "We want to build a service that can help connect everyone around the world so we want to offer that service for free."Facebook ended the quarter with 1.45 billion daily active users, up 13% from a year ago and matching views. It had 2.2 billion monthly active users, also up 13% and meeting estimates.Next up for Facebook is the company's annual developer conference, F8, in San Jose, Calif. The two-day conference starts Tuesday.E-commerce giant Amazon saw its stock spike to an all-time high after it posted better-than-expected first-quarter results late Thursday.Amazon's revenue rose 43% year over year to $51 billion, ahead of the consensus estimate of $49.9 billion. Its adjusted earnings per share surged 121% to $3.27, obliterating analyst predictions for $1.26. It also guided to sales above views for the current quarter.In addition to online shopping, Amazon plays in such fast-growing markets as cloud computing infrastructure services and subscription video on demand.On April 18, Amazon Chief Executive Jeff Bezos revealed in a letter to shareholders that the company has over 100 million paid Prime members globally. Prime offers free shipping, access to Amazon's streaming video and music services, and other benefits.Amazon announced Thursday that it plans to raise the annual cost of Prime membership by 20% to $119, from $99, flexing its pricing power."The Prime program continues to drive great strength in our top line," Amazon Chief Financial Officer Brian Olsavsky said on a conference call with analysts. But costs have been rising as Amazon expands free shipping options and adds more benefits like Prime Video, he said.Internet television network Netflix helped kick off the earnings season on April 16, when it crushed Wall Street's targets for subscriber growth.Netflix added 7.41 million new streaming subscribers in the first quarter, beating its target for 6.35 million. It ended the March quarter with 125 million subscribers worldwide, including 56.71 million in the U.S. and 68.29 million in international markets.For the second quarter, Netflix expects to add 6.2 million subscribers worldwide, topping Wall Street's target of 5.2 million net new subscribers in the period.Netflix credited its subscriber gains to its aggressive push to add exclusive, original content. Popular shows on Netflix include "Stranger Things," "Lost in Space," "Money Heist" and "13 Reasons Why.""We've got some great momentum, and we're very excited about that, but we have a long way to go in terms of earning all of the viewing that we want to," Netflix CEO Reed Hastings said in a conference call with analysts.Alphabet, parent of search giant Google, posted first-quarter results that topped expectations on April 23. It earned $9.93 a share, up 28% year over year, on sales of $31.15 billion, up 26%, in the March quarter. Analysts expected $9.31 and $30.31 billion.Alphabet stock fell on the quarterly report, due to a reported spike in spending, but it has held up relatively well. It has been consolidating for the past 13 weeks, establishing a buy point of 1,198.10.Alphabet has been diversifying beyond its core search advertising business into video content, cloud computing, consumer electronics and self-driving cars.RELATED:FANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google

Weibo (WB) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) are about as different as two stocks on IBD's Global Leaders list can be.Weibo is a China-based microblogging phenomenon. Weibo clocks in at 99. Analyst consensus projects Weibo's first-quarter year-over-year earnings growth will slow slightly, to 85%, atop a 72% revenue surge. Fiat is expected to post an 80% EPS gain, although revenue growth is forecast to slow to less than 3%. Fiat plans to announce first-quarter results April 26. In a volatile week for U.S.-China relations, China stocks trading on U.S. markets predictably posted mixed results.The shake-up was largely the result of the ongoing trade feud, as the Trump administration attempts to restructure the long-standing latticework of trade agreements between the two countries.The clearest pocket of strength among China stocks was in solar components makers. Daqo New Energy (DQ), JinkoSolar (JKS) and JA Solar Holdings (JASO) each posted gains of 8% or more through Friday afternoon. IBD Leaderboard stock Autohome (ATHM) and IBD 50 member Baozun (BZUN) turned in positive performances. Both comfortably maintained support as they consolidated below recent highs.At the same time, the biggest China stocks generally weakened. Baidu (BIDU), JD.com (JD) and Alibaba Group Holding (BABA) all broke down below critical levels of support. In each case, the damage will likely to take some time to repair. In addition, Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) held above its 40-week moving average, and above the prior low in its current two-month-long consolidation.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseValue investors meanwhile snapped up a couple China stocks forming bottoms to long-term consolidations. Among those, Changyou (CYOU) jumped 5%, enough to retake support at its 10-week moving average.Among new issues, IQiyi (IQ) is trading between 15.30 and 16.50 after surging when it went public March 29.The week also produced one breakout for the China stocks. Chemical giant China Petroleum & Chemical (SNP), commonly called Sinopec, broke out past an 89.78 buy point in a cup base. That aced its fifth straight weekly advance.Makers of solar panels had been an early target of U.S. tariffs. In January, the Trump Administration imposed duties of up to 30% on solar components made in China. That news initiated Daqo Solar's current basing pattern. The stock spiked the past week, rising toward a 65.10 buy point in a double-bottom base.China's markets lost ground in a week shortened by the country's Tomb Sweeping Day holiday. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index slipped 0.8%. The Shanghai Composite shed 1.1%. He says iQiyi's subscriber growth could resemble Netflix's in the U.S."We believe iQiyi could add 25 million to 30 million subscribers annually for the next two years and achieve the scale of 100 million memberships by 2019. Combined with Tencent Video, from which we expect a comparable scale and a 40% overlap of users, this implies an adoption rate similar to Netflix's in North America as of today," Chung said.IQiyi also accounts for about 20% of Baidu's revenue."We believe iQiyi could achieve profitability in the long term given the large opportunity for media consumption in the Chinese market and the company's competitive advantages in content offering and distribution despite strong competition from Tencent and Alibaba," Chung added.Baidu rose 0.6% to close at 225.57 on the stock market today. You've likely seen the online boxes or banners hawking: Free Crypto Master Class: Expert Reveals Top Cryptocurrencies Set to Overtake Bitcoin.Or the brokerage firm's pitch: New customers can get a cash bonus or commission-free trades for three months.But wait. Just when you think you've become blind to — or have even blocked — such pesky banners or pop ups, newer ad styles have been cropping up. With names like "native" or "sponsored" advertising, (or in a different structure, affinity marketing) they offer informational or entertaining content.By clicking on such hyped offers, you'll be taken to another site that likely will hit you with a fuller sales pitch.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseWhile designed to blend with the style of the host site, "native" ads may grab you with a jazzy headline — maybe wording like "fast ways to pay off your debt." If you click on the ad, you'd access additional content. And by continuing to click, you'd head deeper into the direct sales pitch.A March 2017 eMarketer report projected that 2017 spending on U.S. native digital display ads overall (not industry-specific) would jump 36.2% vs. the year earlier to $22.09 billion.Consumers may find the ads' free information helpful, while advertisers "are expected to be ethical and transparent," says Michael Uehlein, spokesman for the Data & Marketing Association. Indeed, such ad copy is supposed to state that it is "sponsored," or in some way, "from our advertisers."But it's still advertising, observers note. Imparted information could be limited in scope or skewed. Indeed, shady boasts, such as 'you could have made a 10,000% investment return over the last five years,' could even prove harmful, especially if they entice the needy or unschooled, says Eric Tyson, author of "Personal Finance in Your 20s and 30s For Dummies." Tyson feels such content-style ads, like all marketing, should be viewed skeptically.In the case of "affiliate" or "performance" marketing, a blogger or other content producer may create some kind of informative piece — perhaps highlighting the 10 best credit cards for getting rewards. And if the reader or viewer reacts — commonly by clicking through and buying the products touted — the affiliate will receive a commission. (In this case, the affiliate is supposed to mention in the copy, and near the name of the product, his or her financial arrangement with the advertiser.)For audiences, forms of content marketing seem to draw mixed reviews. Consider this survey by Statista, titled U.S. Consumer Opinion on Sponsored Content as of May 2017. Findings showed the single largest percentage, 43%, believe "there is too much sponsored content," while 33% consider the sponsored content "misleading.""Such content can be helpful if it's about a product or service you need," points out financial planner Matthew McDaniel. "But even if the ad sounds authoritative, it still may be biased. And that can help confuse or even mislead consumers," says McDaniel, founder of Vision Financial Consulting.So how to be careful? Experts offer some tips for avoiding problems with online ads:Financial web sites that author Tyson does recommend for their "quality services" and information: those of T. Rowe Price and Vanguard in the retirement area; and those of E-Trade Financial, Scottrade, T. Rowe Price and Vanguard, which he calls "reliable discount brokers."And if you're looking for a quote on the cost of life insurance, Tyson recommends checking the sites of AccuQuote, ReliaQuote, SelectQuote, Term4Sale and USAA.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Are You Prepared For Big Tax Law Changes This Filing Season?Tax Overhaul Seen Spurring More Hostile Divorce NegotiationsIs This Trump Tax Loophole Open For Interpretation?

The International Energy Agency said Friday that global oil inventories are set to drop below a key benchmark soon, a sign that OPEC and top non-members are nearing the goal of their production cuts.In its monthly report, the IEA said it expects global stockpiles to fall below the five-year average in a "month or two" as inventories are seen falling by 600,000 barrels per day until the end of the year.OPEC and key non-OPEC members like Russia had agreed to curb output by 1.8 million barrels a day to until five-year stockpiles in developed countries returned to average."It is not for us to declare on behalf of the Vienna agreement countries that it is 'mission accomplished,' but if our outlook is accurate, it certainly looks very much like it," the IEA said.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseBrent oil futures rose 0.8% to $72.58 per barrel. U.S. crude climbed 0.5% to $67.39, the highest close since late 2014. U.S. crude rose 8.6% for the week, its biggest gain since July amid tighter global supplies and rising Mideast tensions.Exxon Mobil (XOM) shares edged up 0.8% on the stock market today. Chevron (CVX) was up 0.6%, BP (BP) dipped 0.2%, and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) lost 0.1%.But OPEC and top non-members might not be done with the oil-output pact quite yet. Last month, delegates discussed keeping the five-year average rule but factoring out years of high stockpiles, potentially giving them more leeway to limit production beyond the planned expiration of the deal at year's end, sources told Bloomberg.And while OPEC production is falling, other producers continue to expand, with the oil group raising its guidance for non-OPEC production in it its monthly report Thursday, as crude supplies from the U.S., Canada, Brazil and the U.K. grow.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Energy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalCrude Oil Prices Are Up Sharply, But Is The Bakken Shale Play Back?

OPEC raised its non-OPEC oil production guidance Thursday, as crude supplies from the U.S., Canada, Brazil and the U.K. grow.In its April report, the cartel said it now sees non-OPEC production growing by 1.7 million barrels per day in 2018, an increase of 80,000 bpd. Most of the growth will come from the U.S., which OPEC sees boosting production by 1.5 million bpd.OPEC also upgraded its global demand forecast, predicting growth of 1.63 million bpd, up by 30,000 bpd from its prior report.Brent dipped 2 centsto $72.02 per barrel. U.S. crude rose 0.4% to $67.07, its highest close since December 2014.U.S. crude rose nearly 4% on Tuesday. On Wednesday, crude climbed 2% after President Trump tweeted that he would fire missiles at Syria in response to a suspected chemical weapons attack.Exxon Mobil (XOM) shares fell 0.3% to 77.22 on the stock market today. Chevron (CVX) lost 2 cents to 119.23. BP (BP) was flat and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) dipped 0.45%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseOPEC's production fell by 201,000 bpd in March from February to 31.96 million bpd, according to secondary sources cited in the report, amid its strategy with partner Russia and other nonmembers to curb output by 1.8 million bpd.But higher oil prices along with lower break-even prices have helped U.S. producers ramp up production.On Wednesday, the Energy Information Administration said domestic output last week increased to 10.53 million barrels per day from 10.46 million bpd in the prior week.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Energy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalCrude Oil Prices Are Up Sharply, But Is The Bakken Shale Play Back?

Mylan (MYL) shares rebounded Thursday following worries that first-quarter sales would lag based on tough year-over-year comparisons for allergy drug EpiPen.Those concerns stemmed from commentary during Mylan's investor day, Mizuho analyst Irina Koffler said. On Wednesday, Mylan reiterated its 2018 guidance, but called for tough comparisons for first-quarter adjusted profit and sales of EpiPen."Management indicated that the first half of 2017 contained some nontrivial amount of branded EpiPen sales that may result in slightly tougher comps in the first half of 2018," Koffler wrote in a note to clients.Koffler now expects adjusted income in the first quarter to account for 16.7% of full-year profit, down from 20% in the year-earlier period.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of Use"We therefore pushed sales and earnings further to the second half of 2018," she said. "If Mylan cane get through at least one of its larger approvals expected this summer, we think investors would get more constructive on execution and guidance."She urged investors to buy Wednesday's dip, when shares closed down 2.7%. Investors listened. On the stock market today, Mylan climbed 2.2% to close at 41.26.For 2018, Mylan still expects to report $11.75 billion to $13.25 billion in sales and adjusted profit of $5.20-$5.60 per share. The sales guide is slightly above the consensus for $12.42 billion. At the midpoint, the adjusted profit view is just north of analysts for $5.38.Mylan expects its first-quarter adjusted profit share of full-year earnings to be about 3 base points lower than last year. The firm also expects higher interest expense following recent debt financing, Koffler said.But Koffler has a buy rating and 51 price target on Mylan."We think the stock is undervalued," she said.The firm recently launched a generic copycat of Teva Pharmaceutical's (TEVA) multiple sclerosis drug Copaxone. It views that as a gradual ramp over time, Koffler said.The firm also has key approvals coming this year, including generic versions of Amgen's (AMGN) bone marrow stimulant Neulasta, GlaxoSmithKline's (GSK) inhaler Advair and Allergan's (AGN) eye disease drug Restasis."Management noted FDA may ask for additional clarifications on its Advair application even though all formal information requests have been completed, which led to investor concern about another approval delay," Koffler said. "Management noted that Advair was a 'when, and not if' story."Mylan is also working with Theravance Biopharma (TBPH) on a treatment for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, a condition of the lungs. The Food and Drug Administration is likely to make a decision on that drug in November.RELATED:How Much Money Do You Need To Start Investing?Long-Term Retirement Investing Strategies With ETFsLooking For The Next Nvidia? Guns: While viciously attacking Republicans for opposing gun control, Democrats are celebrating the victory of gun-loving Conor Lamb in the Pennsylvania special election. What would those student gun control protestors say if they knew about that?Lamb defeated his Republican opponent Rick Saccone by a handful of votes in a district that went heavily for Donald Trump. It's being heralded as a referendum on Trump and a bellwether for Democrats prospects in the fall midterm elections.What has barely been mentioned over the past few weeks, however, is the fact that Lamb ran as a something of a poster boy for the NRA.One of Lamb's campaign ads, for example, showed him firing a scary looking assault weapon while the voice over touted his Marine background and said he "still loves to shoot."After the Parkland school shooting, when Democratic leaders were demanding immediate action on gun bans and stoking rage against Republicans, Lamb came out and said that "new gun laws aren't the answer to preventing more mass shootings like the one at a Florida high school."He also came out against a proposed ban on high-capacity ammunition magazines."I believe we have a pretty good law on the books," Lamb said.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseIn effect, Lamb sided with Republicans on what should be done, namely to focus on improving the system of background checks and on mental health issues.As Vox.com put it, Lamb's pro-gun stance "is putting the Democratic Party in a tricky position."That's putting it mildly, given the unbelievably hostile way Democrats have described Republican positions on gun control.Rep. Nancy Pelosi has declared that someone with Lamb's views on guns is nothing more than a "wholly-owned subsidiary of the NRA." Sen. Charles Schumer said at one of the student protests on Wednesday anyone with Lamb's views is in "the viselike grip of the NRA."According to Sen. Diane Feinstein, Lamb's positions, including his opposition to banning the AR-15, aren't just misguided, they are "dangerously wrong"Rep. Elizabeth Esty said that the focus on mental health over gun control "shows either a fundamental lack of understanding or incredible unwillingness to face reality." To Sen. Richard Blumenthal, it's just "an excuse for inaction."By late night talk show host Jimmy Kimmel's definition, Lamb is one of those "crazies" on guns.To liberal activist group MoveOn.org, Lamb's views on guns puts him squarely in the "tiny group of people (who) are holding the rest of our lives hostage. The blood is on their hands."And by Hollywood liberal director Judd Apatow's standard, Lamb's position on gun control makes him "a dangerous idiot who is too much of a coward to reject the NRA."Of course, none of these politicians, organizations, or celebrities will turn their flame throwers on Lamb, because, well, he's a Democrat who might help Democrats regain the House, which would then allow the party to do still more pointless posturing on gun control.Just a few days ago, Pelosi said that gun control was so important that "I would rather pass gun safety legislation than win the election." Right.We've got nothing against pro-gun Democrats. We wish there were more of them, and that we could then have a sensible debate on the issue.But the Democratic Party can't get away with calling Republicans blood-soaked monsters while cheering a candidate who shares the GOP's pro-gun views. Even a high school student can understand that.YOU MIGHT ALSO LIKE:Obama Can't Stop Lying About GunsWe Banned Assault Weapons Before ... It Didn't WorkOther insights on gun control and the Second Amendment

A couple of relatively obscure biotechs are challenging the likes of Novartis (NVS) and Gilead Sciences (GILD) with a new form of treating cancer that not only could undercut their bigger rivals, it could render recently approved oncology drugs from those drug giants obsolete.X Novartis and Gilead are still in the early stages of launching their respective drugs called Kymriah and Yescarta, which are known as CAR-T drugs. But Cellectis (CLLS) and Crispr Therapeutics (CRSP) — each with a tiny fraction of their rivals' market cap — already are creeping in with an off-the-shelf variation on CAR-T therapy that uses healthy donor cells to create a less expensive version of these cancer drugs.This could make treatments from Novartis and Gilead "less attractive or obsolete," Instinet analyst Christopher Marai told Investor's Business Daily."Never mind pricing. (These) could be dosed more effectively," Marai said.CAR-T therapy is a form of oncology treatment currently created by extracting immune cells from a patient's blood. Using an "empty" virus, drugmakers affix what are known as chimeric antigen receptors to the immune system T cells.These receptors, also known as CARs, are proteins that can recognize other proteins used by cancer cells to hide in the body. When these re-engineered T cells are reintroduced to the body, they are directed to seek out and destroy cancer cells carrying those proteins.But the process is complex and costly. It's also tailored to individuals, meaning these drugs can't be mass produced and often take weeks to manufacture. Some patients die while they're waiting, Crispr Chief Executive Sam Kulkarni told Investor's Business Daily.His off-the-shelf approach to CAR-T is aiming to change that.Off-the-shelf CAR-T, also known as allogeneic, uses healthy donor cells to prompt the same immune response as first-generation CAR-Ts that Novartis and Gilead are using, known as autologous. Kulkarni says the donor cells are typically healthier, allowing for a more robust response in patients.The manufacturing process is less complex and, from one run, could make hundreds of doses, Kulkarni said. And because the process is uniform, it's less costly. Cellectis has estimated its cost of goods at less than $5,000 per patient. Autologous CAR-T runs into the hundreds of thousands of dollars, experts say.Kulkarni and Marai note the benefits of allogeneic CAR-T could be huge if the theory pans out in late-stage clinical testing.Healthy donor cells could also prompt a better response than using compromised T cells from a cancer patient, they say. Patients could also potentially receive repeat doses if the benefit doesn't persist from one dose. That's difficult with the much pricier autologous CAR-T."Overall, allogeneic is so much more powerful because it's off-the-shelf," Kulkarni said. "A patient can be treated the very next day. They (allogeneic CAR-Ts) have a good chance of working better than autologous CAR-Ts and they can be accessible broadly to patients."But this theory is still a little short in the tooth. In December, Cellectis with partners Servier and Pfizer (PFE), a Dow Jones industrial average component, unveiled the results of its first clinical trial that used donor cells to create a CAR-T treatment for a form of leukemia.Brad Loncar, who runs the biotech fund known as Loncar Cancer Immunotherapy ETF (CNCR), called the results mixed. In patients with a form of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, the drug known as UCART19 resulted in an 83% complete remission rate across adult and pediatric patients.Use IBD's MarketSmith For Free Until March 11

See stocks near a buy point, get chart pattern recognition and run custom screens. Start NowThe data weren't as strong as results from Juno Therapeutics — formally acquired by Celgene (CELG) earlier this week — when it was at that point. In Phase 1 data presented in December 2016, Juno's JCAR017, a first-generation CAR-T drug, achieved a 93% remission rate in children with the same form of leukemia."If they had equal (effectiveness), of course the off-the-shelf CAR-T would make (first-generation CAR-T) obsolete," Loncar told Investor's Business Daily. "If they have equal (effectiveness), that's a gigantic thing to say and it's far from proven. And there's reason to believe that it will never be so."Allogeneic CAR-T could be the "holy grail" of oncology therapies, said Nadeem Sheikh, vice president of research and development for privately held Dendreon Pharmaceuticals. Dendreon makes an immunotherapy treatment called Provenge for advanced prostate cancer."The entire cancer field would love something like an allogeneic approach," he told Investor's Business Daily. "The allogeneic approach is: I could take your cells and give them to me. That's the holy grail. But we know there's a lot of problems with that approach."Using a donor's cells could introduce the potential for a condition known as graft-versus-host disease, Sheikh said. With that disease, the donor immune cells don't recognize their surroundings and begin to indiscriminately attack everything that appears foreign.Crispr's Kulkarni thinks he has the answer. The company's gene editing process uses a technique called CRISPR in which a receptor on the donor's T cells is removed, preventing those cells from wildly attacking unintended targets."Essentially, by using CRISPR we change the genetics of the healthy donor's T cells," he said. "When we do that, they no longer will indiscriminately attack the patient's cells. They only attack the tumor within the patient."By performing a second edit, the donor T cells are then engineered to appear as if they belong in the body so the patient's own immune cells won't try to destroy the donor cells, Kulkarni said. This allows the donor cells to persist longer in the body."Think of CRISPR as like a blow torch," he said. "You can actually cut metal and weld metal with it. Here, we can either add genes or remove genes from a cell. Essentially we take a healthy person's T cells and make the CAR-Ts by adding or subtracting genes."Cellectis is in a class of its own in allogeneic CAR-T, Loncar said. Its Servier/Pfizer-partnered drug, UCART19, already has preliminary Phase 1 data. Its own drug, UCART123, is in testing in acute myeloid leukemia and a form of leukemia known as blastic plasmacytoid dendritic cell neoplasm.In February, Cellectis was granted a pair of U.S. patents to use CRISPR gene editing for the genetic engineering of T cells. Cellectis said it plans to make these patents available for licensing to other companies willing to use CRISPR technology in T cells.The theory is catching on quickly, even among the biggest first-generation CAR-T players. Gilead announced its acquisition of Kite in late August. The merger closed on Oct. 3 just before the FDA approved Kite's drug Yescarta on Oct. 18. Now Gilead is eyeing the allogeneic approach.Last month, Gilead partnered with Sangamo Therapeutics (SGMO) for $150 million up front to develop cellular therapies using a technique of gene editing called zinc finger nucleases. This process of gene editing is more complex and costly than the CRISPR technology used by Crispr, Editas Medicine (EDIT) and Intellia Therapeutics (NTLA).Under terms of its deal with Gilead, Sangamo is eligible for up to $3.01 billion in potential payments across 10 or more products. The two will work on autologous and allogeneic approaches to cellular therapy.Crispr, the biotech, also is working on an allogeneic CAR-T therapy called CTX101. Like Yescarta from Gilead and Kymriah from Novartis, it targets the CD19 protein, meaning it could potentially be used to treat similar blood cancers. So far, the firm has had three meetings with the FDA to discuss filing an investigational new drug application, Kulkarni said.Such an application would allow Crispr to begin a clinical trial. Kulkarni expects to file an application by the end of the year to begin clinical testing in 2019. He's bullish on Crispr's prospects, but notes it will "take a lot of up-front time and energy.""I think we're still in early days," he said. "We have to see how the data bear out and autologous CAR-T has a head start with a number of trials. But if allogeneic starts working in one tumor type, it's a very scalable program."RELATED:Chart-Reading Basics: How A Buy Point Marks A Time Of Real OpportunityHow To Tame A Volatile Swing Trade With A Half PositionLooking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Deal activity is ticking up in the robust shale sector, with oil major Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) and private equity firm Blackstone Group (BX) partnering to buy BHP Billiton's (BBL) U.S. shale assets, while Chesapeake Energy (CHK) may sell some Louisiana holdings to Tellurian (TELL).X BHP Billiton, an Anglo-Australian mining company, is set to receive multiple offers including a $10 billion joint bid from Royal Dutch Shell and Blackstone Group, according to Sky News.As U.S. oil booms, private equity companies are on the hunt for assets in the shale industry. Devon Energy (DVN) announced the sale of shale assets worth $553 million two days ago, reportedly to a private equity buyer.Meanwhile, Houston-based Tellurian is in talks to buy shale pioneer Chesapeake's drilling fields in Louisiana, which are valued at $2 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported late Thursday, citing unnamed sources.Chesapeake Energy has moved aggressively to reduce its debt burden, in part through property and asset sales. Company executives have focused on selling assets in natural gas, which they say is "out of favor" in the markets. Meanwhile, Tellurian seeks to become a producer as well as exporter of natural gas.Talks between the two companies are tentative, with Tellurian offering to take equity as part of the sale.Tellurian founder Charif Souki, the former chief of Cheniere Energy (LNG), plans to build a coastal facility to sell fuel overseas, the Journal said.Blackstone Group popped about 2% amid the news Friday and BHP rose 1.3%, while Royal Dutch Shell was up 0.2%, on the stock market today. Chinese electric-car startup Nio, which includes Baidu (BIDU) and Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) among its investors, is setting up for an initial public offering that reportedly seeks to raise $2 billion.X The IPO could pose a challenge to Tesla (TSLA), which Nio founder and Chief Executive William Bin Li has taunted in the past.Founded in 2014, Nio launched its first vehicle in December, a fully electric sport-utility vehicle, the Nio ES8, that is priced well below the Tesla Model X sport utility."Tesla is a company founded in the era of the internet, while Nio was born in the era of mobile internet," said Li at the ES8 launch in December, as quoted by the South China Morning Post. "The new era, in which smartphones and apps play a much bigger role in people's daily lives, gives companies like us a great opportunity to revolutionize the automobile industry."The South China Morning Post said Nio planned to raise $2 billion with the IPO, information it said came from a person familiar with the matter. The IPO would give Nio a valuation of $15 billion.In addition to being backed by China search engine giant Baidu and Tencent, which is China's leader in mobile messaging and gaming, Nio also has the backing of China smartphone manufacturer Xiaomi. On Wednesday, Baidu announced it is taking its video streaming service public in the U.S., a company called iQiyi, which aims to raise $1.5 billion.A report from Reuters said Nio has hired eight banks, including Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, to work on a planned U.S. stock market listing this year worth up to $2 billion, people with knowledge of the matter told Reuters.China began promoting electric cars in 2009 and aims to become a dominant global producer. It currently is the world leader in solar power production. Nio is one of a few dozen electric car manufacturers in China, a rising wave of Tesla challengers that also include Byton and Xpeng.Tesla stock fell 2.3% to close at 343.06 on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Tesla presented a fourth-quarter earnings report early this month with few surprises and an outlook by Tesla of business-as-usual, as analysts maintained price targets and ratings on Tesla. Chief Executive Elon Musk said 2018 will be a "transformative year."Nio wants to launch the IPO in the second half of this year as it seeks fresh capital to finance its expansion and investments in areas including autonomous driving and battery technologies, Reuters said.Shanghai-based Nio was formerly known as NextEV. It has vowed to bring an autonomous electric vehicle to the U.S. by 2020.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:With No Sizzle In Tesla Earnings Report, Stock Falls As Analysts YawnBMW Setting Up To Outrun Tesla In Autonomous, Electric-Car FieldJD.com Launches Effort To Advance Artificial Intelligence, BlockchainBest Chinese Stocks To Buy And Watch

U.S. crude supplies rose by 2.4 million barrels last week, the Energy Information Administration said on Wednesday, while U.S. oil production continued to climb.X Domestic production rose by 86,000 barrels per day to around 10.4 million. Gasoline inventories decreased by 800,000 barrels last week.Late Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade group, said that crude inventory rose by 5.7 million barrels last week. Expectations were for a 2.5 million barrel increase, according to an S&P Global Platts poll of analysts, MarketWatch said.U.S. crude prices sank 2.3% to $61.15 a barrel on Wednesday.IBD'S TAKE: For more oil-industry news, check out IBD's coverage of the CERAWeek 2018 energy conference in Houston.Also Wednesday, Exxon Mobil (XOM) outlined a plan to double earnings and cash flow from operations by 2025.That plan includes a fivefold increase in tight-oil production from the U.S. Permian Basin and starting 25 project startups worldwide in Exxon's upstream business. In its downstream business, the company plans to upgrade its products through investments at refineries in the U.S., Europe and Asia.Exxon Mobil said it expects to grow manufacturing capacity in North America and Asia-Pacific by roughly 40%, partly by adding 13 new facilities.The weekly numbers from the government come as OPEC's agreement to set production limits, which have helped push crude prices up, are set to expire by year-end. Meanwhile, U.S. shale growth in the years ahead is expected to be massive."We cannot ignore the growth coming from shale," IEA Executive Director Fatih Birol said on Monday at CERAWeek, an energy conference in Houston. "It is coming very strongly and will affect behaviors, decisions, and strategies of established producers but others as well. It will affect everybody. In a shale revolution world, no country is an island."Exxon fell 2.5% to 74.26 in the stock market today, setting a new two-year low. Exxon shares plunged last month on weaker-than-expected earnings. Fellow Dow Jones energy stock Chevron (CVX), which also missed on earnings last month, rose 0.2%.Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) retreated 1.1%. BP (BP) was off 0.6%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:This Could Be Next Big Oil & Gas 'Super-Basin' After PermianConocoPhillips: We 'Didn't Drill Our Brains Out' Like Shale Rivals DidWhy Saudi Aramco Isn't Worried About EVs, Peak Oil; IPO Is Going WellContinental Resources, Parsley Energy, Matador Beat, See Output Growth

S&P 500 futures, along with Dow Jones futures and Nasdaq futures, fell modestly Tuesday morning. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones rose Monday, but hit resistance at their 50-day lines. Investors await President Donald Trump's Tuesday afternoon announcement on whether to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal.Alibaba (BABA), Salesforce (CRM), Red Hat (RHT), Splunk (SPLK) and ServiceNow (NOW) are top stocks near buy points with two particularly bullish traits.The S&P 500 index, Dow Jones and Nasdaq composite extended Friday's strong rally. However, the S&P 500 and Dow Jones briefly crossed above their 50-day moving averages but once again found resistance at that key level. President Trump tweeted that he will announce his Iran nuclear deal decision at 2 p.m. ET.That announcement seemed to sap the stock market rally, as crude oil futures retreated below $70 a barrel in electronic trading. Crude futures were still just below $70 Tuesday morning. Crude prices, and oil stocks, have rallied on rising odds that Trump will exit the Iran deal, but investors appeared to lock in some profits ahead of his announcement.The stock market is at a key juncture, especially as many top stocks break out or set up near buy points.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Brent gained 2.7% to $67.02 a barrel, getting a lift on a Reuters report that an explosion in Libya took out a pipeline that feeds into the Es Sider port, losing about 90,000 barrel per day.EOG Resources broke out of a 108.95 entry point as shares climbed 2.15% to 109.41 on the stock market today, hitting a three-year high.  Volume was well below normal. Volume was very light for both BP and Shell, following low-trade breakouts Thursday.Exxon Mobil (XOM) shares rose 1 cent to 83.98. Exxon Mobil, a Dow industrials component, is consolidating in a flat base with an 84.34 buy point.IBD'S TAKE: As an investor, you may wonder why buy points are important. The chart action of these top stocks offers an answer.Chevron (CVX), Exxon's Dow peer, edged up 0.8% to 125.98 after clearing its 120.99 entry point last week.  Diamondback Energy (FANG) climbed 1.3% to 125.97 Tuesday after breaking out of a flat base with a 115.03 entry point on Wednesday. Chevron is still in buy range, while Diamondback is increasingly extended.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:These Oil, Mining Stocks Hit Buy Zones On Global Growth, Trump Tax CutsEnergy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalWhy Saudi Arabia Is Now Shopping Around For U.S. Shale AssetsCould These 10 Growth Stocks In The IBD 50 Have A Banner 2018?

Have you heard about the lottery winner who was arrested for defecating on her boss's desk before quitting her job? Or that former President Obama tried to ban the Pledge of Allegiance in our schools just before leaving office?Both these internet-based stories have gone viral, reaching millions of users on Facebook. But there's a problem with these revelations — they're both patently false.X Facebook, Google, Twitter and other Silicon Valley giants have made it easy to propagate misleading, inaccurate and false clickbait news and stories. They've taken only sparse and tentative steps to stop the spread of misinformation. This needs to change.The cause of the fake news epidemic is simple — companies prioritize profit over social responsibility. These firms' executives publicly condemn fake news. Their business models, however, dictate that any crackdowns will be little more effective than window dressing.Social media platforms are free. They generate revenue by selling ads. The more users there are, the more the platform can charge for advertising space. Facebook, for instance, has more than 2 billion users, the most of any online social network. Less than five years ago, it had just 1 billion.That growth has enabled it to hike ad prices. The cost to an advertiser per one thousand impressions for mobile ads is up 29% in just the last three months.  In the second quarter of this year, Facebook's profit hit nearly $4 billion — a 70% increase over the previous year's figure.To attract and keep users engaged, these companies need to curate entertaining and provocative content. To that end, social media companies use algorithms to identify popular articles and posts — regardless of their validity — and place them in prominent view within users' news feeds.No Hidden Agenda: Get News From A Pro-Free Market, Pro-Growth PerspectiveToday, anyone can reach an unprecedented number of people in the blink of an eye at virtually no cost. For example, fastfollowerz.com charges only $250 for 25,000 Twitter users to retweet a post to their own followers. Those followers can then retweet and share the post to more followers, and so on.One analyst reported that by the end of the 2016 election, fake news stories were spreading faster on Facebook than verifiable news stories published by prominent media outlets.The public's inability to distinguish between factual claims and misinformation poses a danger to our society.After news anchor Megyn Kelly clashed with then-candidate Donald Trump in August 2016, the website End the Fed falsely claimed that Fox News executives had fired Kelly for being "a closet liberal who actually wants Hillary to win." Facebook promoted the article in its Trending News section. The story and accusations were fake. But the avalanche of online hate and harassment was very real.Late last fall, bloggers spread a fake news article accusing Hillary Clinton of running a child sex-trafficking ring out of Comet Ping Pong, a Washington, D.C., pizza spot. A 28-year-old with an AR-15 took justice into his own hands, "self-investigated" the posted story, and threatened an innocent employee.Things haven't improved in the last year. In October, several tweets circulated photos of comedian Sam Hyde and incorrectly identified him as the perpetrator of the mass shooting in Las Vegas. Other purveyors of fake news claimed that the sniper was an anti-Trump Democrat and that the motive for the attack was linked to his dislike of Trump. The stories were shared thousands of times on Facebook.The social media companies that enable this chaos to continue portray themselves as champions of social responsibility. Alphabet, Google's parent company, swapped its former "Do no evil" motto for a new code of conduct: "Do the right thing." Similarly, Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg and Twitter co-founder Biz Stone have publicly defined their technologies as agents of social good. But their attempts to rein in fake news have been lackluster.Last November, Google announced it would stop placing ads on nonreputable sites. Yet this month, ads promoting fake news stories were featured on, of all places, the fact-checking websites PolitiFact and Snopes.This month, Facebook announced that it would include links to Wikipedia entries on publishers in its news feed in hopes of helping readers detect outlets peddling fake news. But it's unrealistic to think that users will do background research on each and every publication they encounter.These tech giants are far from struggling startups. They are some of the most profitable companies in the world and have become integral to the very fabric our lives. Given their vast influence, privileged positions and near-bottomless resources, they have an obligation to create a viable, cohesive strategy that stems the dissemination of false information.

China-based Vipshop Holdings (VIPS) soared Monday following news that Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) and JD.com (JD) will invest $863 million in the online discount retailer.X Vipshop shares catapulted 39.2% higher to close at 11.75 on the stock market today. The deal was announced late Sunday.Tencent, China's leader in online messaging and gaming, will invest $604 million and receive a 7% stake in Vipshop. JD.com, a leading e-commerce retailer that competes most directly against Alibaba (BABA), will invest $259 million for a 5.5% stake.Tencent and JD.com paid a 55% premium for the shares, which are subject to a two-year lockup period. The two will have the right to appoint a director and an observer to Vipshop's board of directors during the lockup period.The deal is seen is an attempt to defend against Alibaba, China's leading provider of e-commerce services. In October, JD.com and Tencent expanded their partnership with the launch of a retail marketing platform.As part of the new agreement, Tencent will grant Vipshop a spot on the Chinese version of the popular WeChat communication platform, called Weixin Wallet. JD.com will grant Vipshop a prominent position on its main page and within its mobile application and will assist Vipshop in achieving certain gross merchandising volume targets through JD.com's e-commerce platform.IBD'S TAKE: JD, Tencent and Alibaba are among the best Chinese stocks to buy and watch.  To get a leg up on the stock market going forward, here's a thorough explanation of what to focus on."We will develop a holistic cooperation with Tencent on the Weixin platform and expand our strategic alliance with Tencent into more and broader areas," said Eric Ya Shen, Vipshop's chief executive, said in prepared remarks.Tencent reported third-quarter results in November that beat estimates on the top and bottom line, fueled by strong growth in mobile gaming and video-related subscription services.Alibaba, last month, said it will invest $2.88 billion for a 36.16% stake in Hong Kong-based Sun Art Retail to expand opportunities in food and grocery retailing.Shares of JD.com were up 3.4% to finish the regular trading day at 41.68. Alibaba inched down 0.1% to close at 173.37. Tencent shares climbed 1.6% to end the day at 51.10.RELATED:China E-Commerce Sales A Positive Barometer For Alibaba, JD.comChinese Internet Stock On The Comeback Trail

Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA) surged early Thursday after announcing it would slash its workforce by more than a quarter, close several manufacturing facilities and suspend its dividends on ordinary shares.X Teva expects to eliminate a total of 14,000 positions worldwide, more than 25% of its workforce, over the next two years. The majority of the reductions are expected to occur in 2018. Most of the affected employees will be notified within the next 90 days.The restructuring plan comes as Teva struggles to pay back $34.7 billion in debt. According to sources cited by Bloomberg earlier this week, Teva is reportedly working with advisory firm Evercore to review its options related to its debt."These are decisions I don't take lightly but they are necessary to secure Teva's future," Chief Executive Kare Schultz said in a prepared statement. Schultz took over at Teva in November."We will implement these changes with fairness and the utmost respect to our colleagues worldwide," Schultz went on to say.By the closing bell on the stock market today, Teva had leapt 10.2% to close at 17.30. During premarket action, it rocketed more than 17%.Under the restructuring plan, Teva expects to cut its total cost base by $3 billion by the end of 2019. This follows an announcement last month that it would combine its generic and specialty drug units and focus solely on the U.S., Europe and emerging markets.More than half of the plan is expected to be achieved by the end of 2018. Teva expects to pay a restructuring charge of at least $700 million, mainly related to severance costs with additional potential charges tied to closures or divestments of plants, facilities, headquarters and offices.IBD'S TAKE: Teva has a poor Relative Strength Rating of 3 out of a best-possible 99, meaning the stock's price performance has lagged over the last 12 months. Better stocks tend to have an RS Rating of 80 or above. Head to IBD's Research page for more on how to spot winning stocks.The drugmaker plans to close or divest a "significant number" of research and development facilities, headquarters and other office locations across the globe. It will review its research programs to prioritize core projects and terminate others to keep a substantial pipeline.Teva also plans to strengthen its generic unit by adjusting prices or discontinuing products. This will allow it to close or divest a number of manufacturing plants in the U.S., Europe, Israel and growth markets.The company will also suspend dividends on ordinary shares and American depository shares. Teva's annual bonus will not be paid in 2017 "due to the fact that the company's financial results are significantly below our original guidance for the year," the firm said in a news release.Teva expects to provide full guidance for 2018 in February and will update its longer-term strategic plan later in 2018.RELATED:Teva's Restructuring Plan: Another Case Of Been Here, Done That?Teva Survives Price Cut As Billionaire Reportedly Mulls StakeGeneric Drug Makers Face Pricing Issues That Other Pharmas Don't

The $1.7 billion Columbia Large Cap Growth Fund III (NFEAX) is way ahead of the broad market as measured by the S&P 500 this year, and that's a nice change from last year. The rebound has a lot to do with the rally by growth stocks vs. value stocks in general, especially technology sector names like Alibaba Group (BABA) and Facebook (FB), says lead manager John Wilson.X Those two holdings are up 101% and 55%, respectively, this year. "Technology this year is anchored by strong performances in internet stocks and semiconductor names and infrastructure (internet platform) software names," Wilson said.The shift has helped the fund. In 2016 the fund edged up 1.26% while the bogey advanced 11.96%. This year going into Wednesday the fund was up 27.58% vs. a 21.30% gain for the S&P 500 and a 26.97% gain by the fund's large-cap growth peers tracked by Morningstar Inc.The fund appears poised to keep riding that wave. Its largest sector as of Oct. 31 was technology, with a 34% weighting. That was more than double its next biggest weighting, which was 15.37% in consumer cyclical stocks. Health care stocks were less than one percentage point behind.In tech stocks, Wilson and co-managers Peter Deininger and Tchintcia Barros are playing several themes. One is a switch by technology consumers. "They are starting to re-architect the different applications they use and software platforms they use," Deininger said. "That benefits some individual software companies like Salesforce.com (CRM) and ServiceNow (NOW)."Another theme involves the companies that create and supply the internet infrastructure — including the cloud — that firms like Salesforce and ServiceNow use to provide their services. "Nvidia (NVDA) helps power some of the computer processing in next-generation data centers," Deininger said. "It also helps drive business for more mundane suppliers, whether they are Micron Technology (MU), supplying underlying memory architecture, or Lam Research (LRCX), providing capital equipment that drives expansion that we see in the semiconductor industry overall."Micron makes several types of computer chips, including dynamic random-access memory (DRAM) and flash memory (NAND), which are increasingly important in cloud computing, artificial intelligence, and augmented- and virtual-reality applications on Apple (AAPL) iPhones and other high-end smartphones, Deininger says.Lam is a semiconductor capital equipment manufacturer. It benefits not only from robust demand for memory chips and a rotation away from old disk drives to solid-state flash-driven drives. It also benefits from the shift to multilayered computer chips and the increasing capital intensity of manufacturing with advanced technologies, Deininger says.After Alibaba's big share-price gain this year, the fund has moderately trimmed its share count in recent disclosures. "These were modest position trims given the stock's strong performance this year," Wilson said. "It had elevated to the point where we took a modest percentage off the table. It reflects the stock's strong price performance and the fact that its relative weighting had increased a lot, so we made trims to bring the relative risk-return down."Wilson and his colleagues still like Alibaba because "it's done a good job of monetizing their mobile user base," he said. "There was some concern when they went public (about three years ago) that that would be a slow process. But they've done a good job of improving the relevance of their ecosystem to the Chinese consumer. And they've done an excellent job of tying in their retail network as a marketplace for them to sell a broad variety of goods and services."He adds that Alibaba has done a good job of developing their infrastructure business like Amazon Web Services and Google Cloud.The fund has made moderate trims to its share count in Facebook for similar reasons. The fund still likes the stock. "Our view is that the company has a tremendously strong global franchise," he said. "They're increasingly effective at monetizing, especially in their core Facebook platform. And they've done a tremendous job of ramping up their Instagram platform, which is smaller but growing quickly."He added, "There are six million advertisers in Facebook and only two million on Instagram. But it is fair to say Instagram will get to six million, so it has a lot of runway." User growth will spur advertiser growth, which will fuel Instagram's pricing power, Wilson says.In addition, he expects the firm to monetize Messenger and WhatsApp. "They have some additional opportunities that are interesting, but not totally clear," he said.As for Facebook's spending, Wilson is not worried. "Clearly they are spending aggressively to address issues of newsfeed-quality issues," Wilson said. "They're addressing those issues head-on and it is relatively well understood by the marketplace at this time."Health care may be the fund's third-largest sector, but it is the fund's biggest overweight vs. the Russell 1000 Growth Index. The fund managers like some biotechnology stocks that offer "new revenue streams driven by new products that are perhaps not well understood by the market," he said.Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) is one. The company's lead drug, Soliris, has been used to treat blood disorders. The company now has approval to begin selling Soliris for treatment of myasthenia gravis, an autoimmune neuromuscular disease. But the stock, trading around 113, is 24% off its 51-week high of 149.34 set Sept. 5 and attempting a rally from its Dec. 7 low of 105.01.RELATED:You Need This Much Retirement Savings At Your Age And Income

U.S. crude stockpiles saw a sharp drop last week, while crude output hit a new high for a seventh straight week, according to Energy Department data Wednesday.X Oil inventories fell by 6.5 million barrels, while gasoline stockpiles rose by 1.2 million barrels.Late Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute, an industry group, said U.S. stockpiles fell by 5.2 million barrels last week. Analysts polled by the Wall Street Journal expected a 3.2 million-barrel stockpile drop with gasoline stockpiles up by 1.1 million barrels.Production rose for the ninth straight week to 9.789 million barrels per day, up from 9.78 million barrels per day in the prior week.Brent crude climbed 1.2% to settle at $64.56 per barrel. U.S. crude rose 0.9% to finish at $58.09.Exxon Mobil (XOM) closed up 0.5% at 82.87 on the stock market today. The stock is consolidating in a flat base with an 84.34 buy point. Chevron (CVX) rose 0.9% to 120.89. The stock extended into buy range on Dec. 4 before falling back into its flat base but it still has a  120.99 entry point.Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) and BP (BP) are also consolidating in flat bases with buy points of 65.93 and 41.65 respectively. Shell rose 0.3% to 65.10. BP climbed 0.8% to 40.95. ConocoPhillips (COP) jumped 3% to 54.25, nearly clearing a 54.32 buy point from a flat base. Total (TOT) gained 1% to 55.14, retaking a 55.14 entry.IBD'S TAKE: As an investor, you may wonder why buy points are important. The chart action of these top stocks offers an answer.On Tuesday, Ineos, the operator of the Forties pipeline in Scotland, said a leak that has kept it shutdown would be fixed in two to four weeks since the leak was discovered on Dec. 11.The reduction in supplies from the pipeline has helped propped up Brent crude prices for the last few weeks.RELATED: Energy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, Coal

Campbell Soup's (CPB) purchase of Synders-Lance (LNCE) and Hershey's (HSY) purchase of Amplify Snack Brands (BETR) as well as acquisition talks between a Humana (HUM)-led group and Kindred Healthcare (KND) are leading a frantic surge in M&A activity.X The latest deals and potential deals follow Disney's (DIS) $66 billion acquisition of most of 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) assets and CVS Health's (CVS) $69 billion buy of Aetna (AET).Campbell Soup will buy Snyders-Lance for $4.8 billion as it looks to expand its foothold in what it called the "better-for-you snacks" market amid slowing sales of its own brands.Campbell announced Monday it will acquire the maker of Pretzels and Cape Cod chips for $50.00 per share in an all-cash transaction."This acquisition will dramatically transform Campbell, shifting our center of gravity and further diversifying our portfolio into the faster-growing snacking category," said Campbell Soup CEO Denise Morrison.Shares of Campbell rose 0.1% to 49.66 on the stock market today, while Snyders-Lance gapped up 7% to 50.04.U.S. candy maker Hershey will pay $12 per Amplify Snack Brands share in a deal valued at $1.6 billion, including debt.Hershey is also seeking a stronger foothold in the fast-growing market for healthy snacks. Amplify's portfolio of brands includes SkinnyPop popcorn.Amplify's shares vaulted 71% to 12, while Hershey erased early losses to close up 0.1% at 114.26, after seizing a 114.04 buy point in Friday trade.Penn National Gaming (PENN) is buying rival casino company Pinnacle Entertainment (PNK) for roughly $2.8 billion.Pinnacle shareholders will receive $20 per share in cash and 0.42 Shares of Penn National common stock for each Pinnacle share.Penn shares lost 2.2% to 29.03 Monday. Pinnacle rose 0.8% to 31.19.Oracle (ORCL) will pay $1.2 billion in cash to buy construction software developer Aconex, an Australian company.Shares of Oracle sank 1.2% to 47.71 on Monday.Humana and two private-equity firms are in advanced talks to acquire Kindred Healthcare, the Wall Street Journal reports.The deal values Kindred, a provider of long-term care facilities, at $4 billion including debt.Humana lost 2.8% Monday. Kindred rose 10.5%.Payment processor Total System Services (TSS) will buy a payment technology company Cayan for $1.05 billion in cash to expand its reach with small- and medium-size businesses.Total System rose 1.5% to 78.96 Monday, hitting a record high.Chinese internet giants Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) and JD.com (JD) announced an $863 million investment in Vipshop Holdings (VIPS), stepping up rivalry with Alibaba (BABA).Tencent will invest $604 million for a 7% stake, while JD.com will invest $259 million to raise its existing stake to 5.5%."Vipshop is the 'Groupon' of China due to their discounted sales events though the company has built a strong franchise in clothing particularly women's clothing," said Brendan Ahern, CIO of Krane Funds Advisors, which offers the KraneShares CSI China internet ETF (KWEB).He added: "VIPS will be highlighted on JD.com's mobile e-commerce platform and on Tencent's WeChat social media platform. Tencent is leveraging their stake in e-commerce platform JD.com in their battle with Alibaba."Tencent added 1.6% Monday, JD jumped 3.4%, Vipshop vaulted 39% and Alibaba gave up 0.1%.RELATED:Tax Reform, Bitcoin Stocks, China Deal Send Indexes To New HighsTax Cut Bill Ignites Stocks, But Breakouts Scarce

One important metric to look for in a stock is an 80 or higher Relative Strength Rating. SK Telecom (SKM) now clears that threshold, with a jump from 80 to 83 Friday. X IBD's unique rating identifies share price action with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The score shows how a stock's price behavior over the trailing 52 weeks stacks up against all the other stocks in our database. History shows that the stocks that go on to make the biggest gains tend to have an 80 or higher RS Rating as they launch their biggest price moves.Looking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Start HereSK Telecom broke out earlier, but has fallen back below the prior 28.23 entry from a cup without handle. In the scenario where a stock breaks out then falls 7% or more below the entry price, it's considered a failed breakout. If that happens, it's best to wait for a new base to form. Also keep in mind that the latest consolidation is a later-stage base, which makes it riskier to establish a new position or add shares to an existing one. Earnings growth increased last quarter from 124% to 137%. But sales fell from 3% to 1%. SK Telecom earns the No. 3 rank among its peers in the Telecom Services-Foreign industry group. Investment bank Morgan Stanley on Thursday cut its price target on Apple (AAPL) stock, bringing up yet more concerns about slowing iPhone X sales.Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty reduced her price target on Apple to 200 from 205, but maintained her overweight rating on the stock. She cited slowing iPhone X demand as a factor in her price cut.X Apple's faster-than-expected production ramp of the iPhone X, following earlier snags, could lead to the company beating consensus numbers for the December quarter when it posts its fiscal first quarter results on Feb. 1, Huberty said."We agree with the market view of a December-quarter earnings beat," Huberty said in a note to clients. "Apple produced as much as 6 million to 7 million more iPhone X units than we originally modeled."Apple shares dropped 1.8% to close at 171.11 on the stock market today. Apple hit a record high of 180.10 on Jan. 18 before Wall Street analysts started weighing in with worries about declining demand for the company's flagship smartphone.IBD'S TAKE: Apple stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 86 out of a best-possible 99. For more analysis on Apple, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.In the last two weeks, Apple has been the subject of at least two analyst downgrades and one price-target cut.For her part, Huberty now expects December-quarter iPhone shipments of 80 million units, vs. her prior view of 76 million. She sees the iPhone average selling price hitting $819 in the quarter, thanks to more premium-priced iPhone X units.Huberty now believes Apple will earn $4.12 a share on sales of $92.2 billion, up from her earlier forecast of $3.79 and $86.3 billion. On average, analysts are modeling Apple to earn $3.80 a share on sales of $86.75 billion.Huberty said she disagrees with the prevailing Wall Street view that Apple will guide estimates lower for the March quarter. But she lowered her iPhone sales estimates in the March quarter to reflect a pull-in of iPhone X shipments to the December quarter.Nomura Instinet on Thursday lowered its price targets on seven Asian companies involved in iPhone production, citing recent iPhone order cuts. It downgraded three of those suppliers to neutral from buy.Of the seven, only Himax Technologies (HIMX), is traded in the U.S. Nomura cut its price target on Himax to 10 from 12, but maintained its buy rating.Himax gained 3.5% to close at 8.36."We have observed further order cuts for the iPhone X in the past two weeks," Nomura said in a report. For the first quarter, it now sees production of 18 million units, vs. its prior estimate of 23 million. For the second quarter, it sees 13 million units, down from its earlier estimate of 19 million.RELATED:Apple Stock Drops On Growing iPhone Sales ConcernsApple HomePod Available Feb. 9 After Missing Holiday SeasonApple Stock Hit With Second Downgrade In A Week
